title: How to Preserve Leaves With Silica

steps.headline: Place the microwave-safe container on a flat work surface, such as the kitchen table.
Pour the silica gel into the container so that it covers the base of the container.
steps.description: It should reach about 1 inch (2.5cm) in height.

steps.headline: Prepare the leaves.
steps.description: Shorten the stems of the leaves if they're longer than 1 1/2 inches (3.27cm).

steps.headline: Arrange the leaves across the surface of the silica in the container.
Pour in more silica gel over the top of the leaves sitting on the other silica gel.
steps.description: Do this very slowly and with care not to cause folds in the leaves. There should be enough silica gel to cover the leaves.

steps.headline: Put the glass of water into the microwave.
steps.description: Add the container of leaves and silica.

steps.headline: Microwave the container on medium power.
steps.description: Initially microwave for 1 minute, then check and try another minute. You are looking for the leaves to have dried, which will take about 2-3 minutes.

steps.headline: Remove the container from the microwave.
steps.description: Pour the silica gel into another container, slowly and carefully. Any silica still on the leaves can be brushed off with your fingers or a paintbrush or other suitable small soft brush.

steps.headline: Spray glaze or dried flower coating over the leaves.
steps.description: This step is optional but it will help prolong the life of the preserved leaves by strengthening them. Follow the instructions on the packaging.

steps.headline: Use the leaves.
steps.description: You can include the silica-preserved leaves in floral arrangements, artwork, craft projects, and as decoration on wrapping, cards, and pictures, etc.

text: Place the microwave-safe container on a flat work surface, such as the kitchen table.  Pour the silica gel into the container so that it covers the base of the container. It should reach about 1 inch (2.5cm) in height. Prepare the leaves. Shorten the stems of the leaves if they're longer than 1 1/2 inches (3.27cm). Arrange the leaves across the surface of the silica in the container.  Pour in more silica gel over the top of the leaves sitting on the other silica gel. Do this very slowly and with care not to cause folds in the leaves. There should be enough silica gel to cover the leaves. Put the glass of water into the microwave. Add the container of leaves and silica. Microwave the container on medium power. Initially microwave for 1 minute, then check and try another minute. You are looking for the leaves to have dried, which will take about 2-3 minutes. Remove the container from the microwave. Pour the silica gel into another container, slowly and carefully. Any silica still on the leaves can be brushed off with your fingers or a paintbrush or other suitable small soft brush. Spray glaze or dried flower coating over the leaves. This step is optional but it will help prolong the life of the preserved leaves by strengthening them. Follow the instructions on the packaging. Use the leaves. You can include the silica-preserved leaves in floral arrangements, artwork, craft projects, and as decoration on wrapping, cards, and pictures, etc.
